options: Tell the patient that you are unable to make the referral and that she must find another time to make an appointment to see a different doctor
Discuss with your supervisor the situation and reflect on how you will manage such situations in your future practice
Present the patient with options regarding family planning, but do not give any information regarding TOP
Discuss with the patient all of the options available to her
Make an appointment with another GP in the practise who you know is happy to make TOP referrals
Ask that she comes back to see you with the father of the child so you can discuss the possibilities
Review whether she has any history suggestive of STD
Perform a full examination
questions:
You are in a GP rotation and a 21-year-old patient 8 weeks pregnant attends requesting a termination of pregnancy. You are unable to make the referral due to conscientious objection.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question assesses your ability to apply the GMC guidelines around conscientious objection. Although you may not object, it is important that you understand and can apply the guidelines. To read these see: http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/21177.asp

In this case, it will be useful to discuss the situation with your supervisor (option 2), both to ensure you have taken the correct course of action, but also to learn from it. It will be important to present all the options to the patient (option 4), and then presuming she wishes to proceed with a termination, to make an appointment with a doctor who is able to make the referral (option 5).

Option 1 is worse, as that is putting the responsibility for referral back on a potentially vulnerable patient and requiring her to do the work. Option 3 goes against the GMC guidance. Although it would be good practice to seek to understand the social circumstances, you cannot demand that she attends with the father. Although options 7 and 8 may be good practice, in this case they are not the best options for dealing with the matter in hand.

options: Immediately bleep the on-call consultant to come now and deal with the complaint personally
Tell Mr Lewis that complaints will delay his care and suggest he waits until after discharge
Invite Mr Lewis to a quiet space, listen without interruption, acknowledge his concerns, and offer a clear apology for the experience and impact
Reassure him that the staff member will be disciplined and promise a complaint’s outcome
Provide written information for PALS and offer a complaint form if available, and explain what will happen next
Downplay the delay and avoid references to the conversation he overheard when documenting, to avoid the complaint involving numerous unnamed staff members
Advise him to post on social media to achieve a faster response and provide the ward name
Explore any immediate needs that can be addressed now and agree simple, practical remedies to stop the complaint
Document the conversation objectively in the notes and notify the nurse in charge/ward manager so the concern is logged and actioned
Tell him you cannot discuss staff behaviour and provide him with details for HR to raise his concerns
questions:
A 58-year-old man, named Mr Lewis, is angry and says he wants to make a formal complaint. He reports that yesterday, a staff member spoke to him rudely, his pain medication was two hours late, and this morning, he overheard nurses discussing his case at the desk where other patients could hear. He remains clinically stable and has no urgent medical needs right now. He asks you: “Who do I speak to? I want this on record.”

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Invite Mr Lewis to a quiet space, listen without interruption, acknowledge his concerns, and offer a clear apology for the experience and impact is most appropriate. The GMC expects doctors to be open, honest and compassionate when things go wrong or cause distress. A sincere apology is not an admission of liability; it’s part of the professional duty of candour and helps de-escalate while showing respect.

Provide written information for PALS and offer a complaint form if available, and explain what will happen next is appropriate. The GMC and NHS complaints regulations require doctors to facilitate complaints and not obstruct them. Giving clear, practical instructions with PALS/complaints team contacts empowers the patient and fulfils organisational duty of candour.

Document the conversation objectively in the notes and notify the nurse in charge/ward manager so the concern is logged and actioned is most appropriate. Contemporaneous documentation supports transparency, ensures the concern isn’t lost, and allows the organisation to investigate patterns (eg. delays, confidentiality lapses). This aligns with raising concerns and organisational learning.

The remaining options are inappropriate/less appropriate:

Immediately bleep the on-call consultant to come now and deal with the complaint personally is inappropriate. Senior involvement can be helpful, but the first steps are to listen, apologise, signpost the formal process, and ensure the concern is recorded. Pulling a consultant away urgently when there is no clinical risk is disproportionate; escalate via the ward manager/line manager in-hours per policy.

Tell Mr Lewis that complaints will delay his care and suggest he waits until after discharge is inappropriate. Discouraging or obstructing complaints breaches openness and can undermine trust. Patients must be able to voice concerns without disadvantage to their care.

Reassure him that the staff member will be disciplined and promise a complaint’s outcome is inappropriate. You shouldn’t prejudge outcomes or make promises outside your authority. The correct approach is to explain the process and that an impartial investigation will be undertaken.

Downplay the delay and avoid references to the conversation he overheard when documenting, to avoid the complaint involving numerous unnamed staff members is inappropriate. Falsifying or retrospectively altering records violates probity and GMC guidance. Records must be accurate; if clarifying, make a dated, signed entry—never withhold relevant information.

Advise him to post on social media to achieve a faster response and provide the ward name is inappropriate. Encouraging public disclosure risks further harm and privacy breaches. The correct route is the formal complaints procedure.

Explore any immediate needs that can be addressed now and agree simple, practical remedies to stop the complaint is inappropriate. Putting problems right where possible is good practice and part of candour. It’s important, but after you’ve listened and enabled the formal complaint and ensured it’s recorded/escalated (therefore not within the most appropriate top three).

Tell him you cannot discuss staff behaviour and provide him with details for HR to raise his concerns is inappropriate. This is dismissive and abdicates your responsibility to facilitate concerns and direct patients to the correct PALS/complaints route.

title: Patient complaints
body:
It is important to be open and respond appropriately when a patient makes a complaint. This may happen through a number of channels:
  • verbal complaint
  • informal or formal written complaint addressed to the doctor concerned
  • complaint addressed to a managing body e.g. hospital trust or GP practice
  • complaint to the GMC

It should of course be remembered that patient complaints or comments may be unwarranted or without basis and therefore a formal reply is usually required to ensure the doctor has given their account of what has happened.

options: Arrange a professional interpreter (telephone/video) now and obtain informed consent through them
Proceed using the son as the interpreter to save time so the theatre slot isn’t lost
Assess and document Mrs Rahman’s decision-making capacity regarding the procedure, using the interpreter; if capacity is present, follow her decision
Escalate to the consultant to decide whether to delay vs proceed under best-interests (if capacity cannot be established), documenting the rationale
Use a general translation app on your personal phone for the consent conversation to avoid delay
Ask the son to sign the consent form on her behalf because he is family
Tell the son that if he insists on interpreting, you will proceed but note his insistence in the record

Document the discussion objectively: need for interpreter, capacity assessment, risks/benefits/alternatives explained, the patient’s decision, and who was present; include any delays and pain measures provided
Cancel the slot as there is no possibility of arranging a professional interpreter to discuss consent prior to theatre
Act in her best interests and proceed to theatre
questions:
A 62-year-old woman called Mrs Rahman presents to the emergency department with a displaced distal radius fracture requiring manipulation under procedural sedation today. She speaks very limited English. Her adult son, who speaks fluent English, says, “I’ll translate—don’t call an interpreter; we’ll miss the theatre slot.”

The emergency department consultant is available; the department has 24/7 telephone/video interpreting. Clinically, the case is urgent but not life- or limb-threatening.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Arrange a professional interpreter (telephone/video) now and obtain informed consent through them is most appropriate. Valid consent requires that the patient understands material risks, benefits, and alternatives in a language they can comprehend. GMC guidance on consent and communication is explicit: use trained interpreters rather than family members for important clinical decisions, particularly where risks include respiratory depression and aspiration from sedation. A 24/7 professional interpreter is available, so you should use them to ensure accuracy, confidentiality, and that consent is informed and voluntary.

Assess and document Mrs Rahman’s decision-making capacity regarding the procedure, using the interpreter; if capacity is present, follow her decision is most appropriate. Capacity is decision-specific and must be presumed, but you must take all practicable steps to help the patient decide—here, that support is a professional interpreter. Using the interpreter, check understanding of the nature of the manipulation and sedation, material risks, reasonable alternatives (splintage and delayed manipulation), and the option of no treatment. If she demonstrates understanding, retention, weighing, and communication, her capacitous decision should be respected and enacted.

Document the discussion objectively: need for interpreter, capacity assessment, risks/benefits/alternatives explained, the patient’s decision, and who was present; include any delays and pain measures provided is most appropriate. Contemporaneous, objective records are a GMC requirement. Detailing the interpreter’s involvement, the capacity assessment, the risks/benefits/alternatives discussed, and the patient’s decision provides transparency and continuity of care. Recording any delay, reasons for it, and interim pain/splintage measures demonstrates patient-centred care and defensible decision-making.

The remaining options are inappropriate/less appropriate:

Proceed using the son as the interpreter to save time so the theatre slot isn’t lost is less appropriate. Relying on family for high-stakes consent risks inaccuracy, omission, and coercion, and undermines confidentiality. GMC guidance on consent and communication is clear: use trained interpreters for important clinical decisions, especially when discussing material risks (eg. aspiration, respiratory depression) and alternatives. Here, a 24/7 professional interpreter is available, so bypassing them would jeopardise the validity of consent and the patient’s autonomy.

Escalate to the consultant to decide whether to delay vs proceed under best-interests (if capacity cannot be established), documenting the rationale is less appropriate. Senior input is valuable if capacity cannot be established after you’ve taken reasonable steps to support understanding (such as arranging a professional interpreter). Because an interpreter is readily available, jumping straight to a best-interests discussion is premature. GMC best practice is to enable the patient to decide for herself before considering best-interests or substitute processes.

Use a general translation app on your personal phone for the consent conversation to avoid delay is less appropriate. Consumer translation apps are unreliable for medical terminology and create information-governance risks (data storage, privacy). They are not suitable for consent discussions where precision and confidentiality are essential. With approved 24/7 telephone/video interpreting available, using a personal app would fall below GMC standards for safe, effective communication.

Ask the son to sign the consent form on her behalf because he is family is less appropriate. Family members do not have legal authority to consent for capacitous adults. If the patient lacks capacity, decisions must follow the proper legal/best-interests framework (and any valid LPA/attorney if present), not proxy signature by a relative. Encouraging a family signature risks invalid consent and contravenes GMC expectations around lawful, patient-centred decision-making.

Tell the son that if he insists on interpreting, you will proceed but note his insistence in the record is less appropriate. Documenting that a relative insisted does not fix the problem: consent obtained via an untrained family member remains unsafe and potentially invalid. Your duty is to take reasonable steps to enable accurate, confidential communication (eg. professional interpreter), not to proceed regardless and try to protect yourself with a note.

Cancel the slot as there is no possibility of arranging a professional interpreter to discuss consent prior to theatre is inappropriate. This option is based on an incorrect premise. The department has 24/7 telephone/video interpreting, so cancellation for lack of an interpreter is unnecessary and not patient-centred. GMC guidance expects you to use available resources to support understanding and proceed once valid consent is obtained.

Act in her best interests and proceed to theatre is inappropriate. Best-interests decisions apply only when capacity is lacking after you’ve taken all practicable steps to help the patient decide (eg. using a professional interpreter). This is an urgent but not life- or limb-threatening case, so there is time to secure proper communication and assess capacity. Proceeding under best-interests now would bypass the patient’s autonomy and fall short of GMC standards.

title: Consent
body:
There are 3 types of consent:

1. Informed
2. Expressed
3. Implied

Consent forms used in UK NHS
Consent Form 1For competent adults who are able to consent for themselves where consciousness may be impaired (e.g. GA)
Consent Form 2For an adult consenting on behalf of a child where consciousness is impaired
Consent Form 3For an adult or child where consciousness is not impaired
Consent Form 4For adults who lack capacity to provide informed consent

Capacity
Key points include:
1. Understand and retain information
2. Patient believes the information to be true
3. Patient is able to weigh the information to make a decision
All patients must be assumed to have capacity

Consent in minors
Young children and older children who are not Gillick competent cannot consent for themselves. In British law the patient's biological mother can always provide consent. The childs father can consent if the parents are married (and the father is the biological father), or if the father is named on the birth certificate (irrespective of marital status). If parents are not married and the father is not named on the birth certificate then the father cannot consent.

options: Take the day off as a sick day
Accept the rota and see if you can find someone to cover you
Accept the rota and miss the wedding
Remind medical staffing of your annual leave, inform them you still want to take leave and ask them to help you find cover
Inform your consultant
questions:
You have your best friends wedding coming up in a few months and so you inform the staffing department to ensure you get the time off work. On receiving your rota, you see you have been scheduled to work the day of the wedding.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Doctors should be able to to maintain a suitable balance between work and personal life.

It is important you highlight the situation and speak with medical staffing to see if they can help resolve the issue. Therefore option D is the best option. This option shows confidence in your ability to try and rectify the error and also an ability to work together in a difficult situation. Involving medical staffing is a better option than trying to sort things about by yourself (B).

Consultants don't really have much sway in terms of annual leave requests (E). They are likely to refer you on to medical staffing. Of course if there was any potential gap on the rota this should be discussed but there is plenty of time still to ensure this does not happen.

Option A is the worst option. Lying about your whereabouts is dishonest and unprofessional. This could also affect patient care due to understaffing issues.

options: Ignore the quetiapine as it would have been used whilst in hospital for sedation
Add the quetiapine to her regular medication
Phone the ward she has been discharged from and ask them to confirm the medications
Ask the receptionists to make a routine appointment to clarify the situation

questions:
You are a GP registrar. After morning surgery you are going through the letters and find a discharge summary for an elderly lady who was admitted following a fractured neck of femur. The summary simply states the diagnosis as '# NOF' and then lists her regular medications. One of the medications listed is quetiapine. On reviewing her records you see that this is a new addition. Her other medications are unchanged.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is not an uncommon dilemma faced by GPs. Was the new medication a mistake? Was it only meant to be given whilst in hospital? Prescribing lactulose or co-codamol in such a situation may be fine but for a medication such as quetiapine (an antipsychotic), with no explanation in the discharge summary, it is best practice to check with the medical team. Phoning the patient may be an option but it is possible (or likely) that the patient simply won't know. Making a routine appointment with the patient does not deal with the problem, simply delays the resolution. Adding quetiapine with checking is problematic for the reasons discussed above.

Ignoring the quetiapine due to your assumptions is the worst option.

options: Call Mrs Watts' GP to discuss her home circumstances
Take Mrs Watts' case to the weekly multi-disciplinary team (MDT) meeting
Reassure Mrs Watts that you will document what she has said and the palliative team will take in to account her wishes
Discuss Mrs Watts' wishes with her family
Tell Mrs Watts' that whilst she is requiring continuous oxygen therapy she should stay in hospital
questions:
Mrs Watts has end stage pulmonary fibrosis and needs continuous oxygen therapy; she is frequently in and out of hospital. During an admission for pneumonia she confides in you that she knows she is dying and wants to die at home. She has a close and large family who she is scared of upsetting so hasn't told them of her wishes.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Good communication is central to good patient care. Listening and reassuring Mrs Watts that you will act on her wishes is the most appropriate thing to do in this situation (C). Once the wishes have been sought they can then be taken to the MDT to ensure that they are implemented (B). Speaking to the GP is also prudent as they will be actively involved in the care once Mrs Watts goes home (A).

It would not be appropriate to give inaccurate information to try to engineer a different end of life pathway (E)

Any decision to break confidentiality (D) can only be made with the agreement of Mrs Watts; it is worth noting that often patients wish for these discussions to be had via their doctor as they are upsetting conversations.

options: Explore his reasons for not wanting to be examined by a female doctor + ask him to see the male GP in two days time
Politely remind him of Equal Opportunities legislation + ask him to rebook another appointment
Apologise for the misunderstanding + suggest the patient attends the Emergency Department
Tell him that he has no choice and that you will have to examine him with the male practice manager as a chaperone
Apologise for the misunderstanding + speak to a male doctor at the practice and ask him to see the patient today
questions:
You are a female doctor based at a GP surgery. The next patient you see is a 19-year-old man complaining of new-onset testicular pain. He is surprised to see you as the receptionists told him that he had been booked in with a male doctor. He declines to let you examine him as he says he is embarrassed. The next routine appointment with a male GP is in two days time.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at the willingness of a doctor to respect the reasonable preferences of a patient. The patient reports that he was told he would see a male doctor. This should be taken at face value so an apology is appropriate (E) and arrangements should be made for him to see a male doctor before leaving as he has presented with a potentially serious complaint.

It is important that care is not delayed. Whilst referring the patient to the Emergency Department (C) may seem poor management from the GP's point of view it protects patient safety.

Whilst 'exploring' the patient's reasoning is often a good option in this kind of question it is clear he is embarrassed and this won't necessarily go away the more you talk about it. It may come across and condescending and seems to ignore the explicit wishes he has already expressed (A). It also introduces a delay in the patient being assessed.

Option B is worse as it starts with you quoting irrelevant legislation (essentially telling the patient off) and then getting him to rebook the appointment (which he may not do out of embarrassment) rather than you being proactive and booking it.

The patient has clearly asked not to be examined. To proceed following this is inappropriate and unwise (D). It is not uncommon that patients may ultimately agree to doctors request due to the perceived status and power of doctors but it is not appropriate to exploit this once his true wishes are known. It is also doubtful whether a non-clinical member of staff should act as a chaperone for an intimate examination.

options: Assess the patient's capacity to make this decision to drive
Contact the police via 999
Contact the neurologist asking them to discuss driving rules with the patient
Report the driver to the DVLA
Re-explain the driving rules to the patient
Contact the patient's employer advising them that the patient should not be driving
Contact the patient's next of kin to advise them of the driving rules
Document driving discussions clearly in the medical notes
questions:
A 35-year-old man is having a review by his general practitioner 2 weeks after being admitted to the hospital with an unprovoked first seizure. During the consultation, the man states that he has decided to continue to drive to work despite his neurologist advising him not to. On further questioning, he has walked to the appointment today.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question explores a difficult situation in which a patient has continued to drive against medical advice and the DVLA driving rules. Due to the patient being aware of the rules and the risks to members of the public, the general practitioner (GP) is required to take action. These actions should include re-explaining the driving rules to the patient, documenting the discussions in the medical notes, and contacting the DVLA. The GP should advise the patient that they will be contacting the DVLA.

Assessing the patient's capacity to make a decision about driving is not the most appropriate answer as it is not a question about having the capacity to make a decision to drive, but instead, the driving rules are mandatory.

'Contact the police via 999' is not the most appropriate answer as the vignette states that the man has not driven today. As there is not an immediate risk to others, calling an emergency phone line would not be appropriate.

'Contact the neurologist asking them to discuss driving rules with the patient' is not the most appropriate answer. Every medical practitioner has a responsibility to discuss driving rules, and simply contacting the neurologist to have this discussion is passing responsibility. As the patient has stated that they will continue to drive, the GP should take action.

'Contact the patient's employer advising them that the patient should not be driving' is not an appropriate answer. For the GP to contact the patient's employer, they would need consent from the patient, otherwise, patient confidentiality may be breached.

'Contact the patient's next of kin to advise them of the driving rules' is an inappropriate answer as it is also a potential breach of confidentiality if the patient has not provided consent for discussions with their next of kin.

title: GMC: Confidentiality: patients' fitness to drive and reporting concerns to the DVLA or DVA
body:
Trust is a central part of the doctor-patient relationship and is part of our daily practice. This can be put at risk by breaking confidentiality. Fitness to drive is one area where it is important to know what is expected of you, in both a legal and moral sense. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)/ Vehicle Agency (DVA) are legally responsible for deciding if a person is medically unfit to drive. This means they need to know if a person holding a driving licence has a condition or is undergoing treatment that may affect their safety as a driver.

First off, it is the driver's legal responsibility to tell the DVLA or DVA about any condition or treatment. Doctors should alert patients to conditions and treatments that might affect their ability to drive and remind them of their duty to tell the appropriate agency. However, doctors may need to make a decision about whether to disclose relevant information without consent if a patient is unfit to drive but continues to do so.

You should always ask for a patient's consent before disclosing information for the protection of others (if it is safe, appropriate or practicable to do so). If it is not possible to seek consent or the patient has refused, disclosing personal information may be justified. This is particularly when there is a risk of death or serious harm to others. The benefits of disclosure must outweigh the interest in keeping the information confidential.

Problems with breaking confidentiality:
  • Patients may avoid seeking medical help, or may under-report symptoms.
  • Consultations may become more strained or mistrusting.
  • Complaints may be made against the doctor or practice.

You should not ask for consent if you have already decided to disclose information in the public interest but, if possible, you should tell the patient about your intention to disclose personal information. If the patient objects to the disclosure you should consider any reasons they give for objecting.

Reasons that the patient may object to sharing of information:
  • They are concerned about the implications for work, family or other areas.
  • In principle, they do not feel that it is your place to share the information.
  • They do not understand the reason for the information sharing.

When deciding whether the public interest outweighs potential harm, consider:
  • The potential harm or distress to the patient arising from the disclosure.
  • The potential harm to trust in doctors generally.
  • The potential harm to others if the information is not disclosed.
  • The potential benefits to an individual or society due to the release of the information.
  • The nature of the information to be disclosed, and any views expressed by the patient.
  • Whether the harms can be avoided or benefits gained without breaching the patient's privacy.

When diagnosing a patient's condition, or providing or arranging treatment, you should consider whether the condition or treatment may affect their ability to drive safely. To help determine this, you can refer to the DVLA's guidance on assessing fitness to drive. You may also seek the advice of an experienced colleague or the DVLA medical adviser.

If a patient has a condition or is undergoing treatment that could impair their fitness to drive, you should:
  • Explain this to the patient and tell them that they have a legal duty to inform the DVLA.
  • Tell the patient that you may be obliged to disclose relevant medical information about them, if they continue to drive when they are not fit to do so.
  • Make a note of any advice you have given to a patient in their medical record.
  • If a patient is incapable of understanding this advice, such as in cognitive impairment, you should inform the DVLA as soon as practicable.

The patient is welcome to seek a second medical opinion, and you should help facilitate this. However, you should still advise them not to drive in the meantime. If you become aware that a patient is continuing to drive when they may not be fit to do so, you should make every reasonable effort to persuade them to stop. Only then, would you consider breaching confidentiality. This is not an easy decision to make, but may be necessary for the safety of others.

options: Phone her boyfriend's parents, advising them of the situation, and suggest they forbid the relationship
Assess using Fraser guidelines + prescribe the COC
Advise her to abstain from sex, refer to a  'Safer Sex for Young Adults' program and discuss her with your colleagues at the next practice meeting
Refuse to help given her age
Immediately phone local child protection lead and refer to social services
questions:
A 12-year-old girl comes with her mother to surgery. She is requesting the combined oral contraceptive (COC) pill as she has recently started a relationship with an 16-year-old boy who she met at the local games arcade, although she has not yet had sex with him. You discuss the age difference but her mother states that she has met the boyfriend and says he treats her well. Both the girl and her mother insist that they do not want anyone else involved.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Children under the age of 13 years are not able to consent to sexual intercourse and hence any sexual activity would be regarded as rape under the law. This is one situation under the GMC guidelines where you are compelled to break confidentiality. Referral to the local child protection lead is therefore the most appropriate option.

Option C is the next best response. The advice is sound (abstention, referral to specialist programme and discussing with the practice), but the seriousness of the situation warrants external, immediate specialist input from child protection.

The next option would be to prescribe the COC. She is likely to have sex regardless of what you advise her to do. By prescribing the pill you are at least reducing the psychological, social and physical risks of an unwanted pregnancy. However, it should be noted that given her age the Fraser guidelines are not considered applicable.

Doing nothing is not in the interests of patient. Option A breaks confidentiality and is the least appropriate response.

options: Assess Mr Patel immediately, perform a focused bleeding assessment and review the notes and drug chart to confirm the error
Amend the drug chart to “5 mg intended” for today and rewrite tomorrow’s dose correctly
Escalate to the on-call surgical SHO/registrar and seek advice on investigations and monitoring/anticoagulation plan overnight
Complete an incident report and document objectively in the notes what happened, including discussions and agreed plan
Explain the error to Mr Patel, apologise, outline the monitoring/management plan, and answer his questions
Ask the nurse to withhold all anticoagulation for 48 hours and recheck INR in the morning without senior input
Contact the on-call haematology/blood bank directly for reversal advice before speaking to your surgical senior
Tell the nurse that no action is needed as the patient looks well and decimal errors are common
Reassure Mr Patel that everything is routine and plan to debrief him only if he develops bleeding
Ask the nurse to complete an incident report
questions:
You are the F1 doctor on an elective surgical ward at 19:15. Mr Ravi Patel, 68, had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy this afternoon. While writing up his evening meds, you notice that he was given 5 mg warfarin instead of the intended 0.5 mg. The error arose because the preceding zero before the decimal was missing on the drug chart (written as “.5 mg”).

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Assess Mr Patel immediately, perform a focused bleeding assessment and review the notes and drug chart to confirm the error is most appropriate. The first priority is patient safety. You must verify the facts (dose, time, indication) and assess for harm (bleeding from wounds, bruising, haematuria/melaena, post-op drain output, haemodynamics). This aligns with GMC guidance to “put the patient’s safety first” before anything else. It also ensures any subsequent discussion under the duty of candour is accurate and informed.

Escalate to the on-call surgical SHO/registrar and seek advice on investigations and monitoring/anticoagulation plan overnight is also most appropriate. A significant medication error in a high-risk patient (mechanical valve and warfarin) needs senior input now for investigations (such as an urgent INR, full blood count and coagulation screen) and a monitoring/anticoagulation plan overnight (eg. observation frequency, reversal vs. watchful waiting, bridging implications). Escalation is part of acting promptly to reduce the risk of harm and is consistent with GMC expectations to seek help when needed.

Explain the error to Mr Patel, apologise, outline the monitoring/management plan, and answer his questions is also most appropriate. This is the professional duty of candour: promptly inform the patient when a notifiable safety incident has occurred or may have caused harm, offer a genuine apology, explain what happened, what will be done to put it right, and what will be learned. Do this in clear, compassionate language and document it.

The remaining options are inappropriate/less appropriate:

Amend the drug chart to “5 mg intended” for today and rewrite tomorrow’s dose correctly is inappropriate. Altering records to suggest the higher dose was intended is falsification. It breaches honesty, undermines safety learning, and violates GMC probity standards. Always correct errors transparently (with dated, signed entries) rather than retrofitting the prescription.

Complete an incident report and document objectively in the notes what happened, including discussions and agreed plan is inappropriate at this time. Although this is the right thing to do, this should be completed after immediate assessment, escalation, and informing the patient. Documenting the facts, your discussion, and the plan, and submitting an incident report meets both organisational duty of candour and learning-from-error obligations. However, it's just not in the top three immediate actions listed here, as assessing the patient, escalating to a senior immediately and informing/apologising to the patient (duty of candour) is most important.

Ask the nurse to withhold all anticoagulation for 48 hours and recheck INR in the morning without senior input is inappropriate. Modifications to anticoagulation risk valve thrombosis vs. bleeding and management must be individualised and senior-led. Acting without escalation can harm the patient and breach GMC expectations to work within your competence and seek advice.

Contact the on-call haematology/blood bank directly for reversal advice before speaking to your surgical senior is inappropriate at this stage. Haematology input may be needed, but the correct route is to escalate within the surgical team first, who can then coordinate specialty advice. Bypassing your senior without urgency or a plan fragments care and communication.

Tell the nurse that no action is needed as the patient looks well and decimal errors are common is inappropriate. A 10-fold warfarin overdose is a significant risk even if the patient is currently stable. Minimising or ignoring the incident compromises safety and learning and fails the duty of candour.

Reassure Mr Patel that everything is routine and plan to debrief him only if he develops bleeding is inappropriate. Withholding the truth contradicts the duty of candour, which requires prompt disclosure, an apology, and an explanation of monitoring/management—even if no harm has yet occurred.

Ask the nurse to complete an incident report is inappropriate. Incident reporting is a shared responsibility, but delegating it to the nurse as your immediate action misses the priorities (assess, escalate, inform). You should ensure it’s completed—ideally by you or jointly—after the urgent steps and clear documentation in the notes.

title: Duty of candour
body:
All healthcare professionals must be honest when something has gone wrong. They must:
  • Tell the patient when something has gone wrong
  • Apologise to the patient (or carer or family member where appropriate)
  • Offer an appropriate resolution
  • Explain the potential short and long-term effects of the error

Important to note:
  • Saying sorry is not an admission of legal liability
  • The patient has a right to receive an apology from 'the most appropriate team member' - this will usually be the lead or accountable clinician
  • The process for reporting adverse incidents and near misses varies between different health organisations: you must follow your own organisations policy
  • The National Report d scheme
